Posts.Title: The prognosis in not good RobinWendy BrokenHeart

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2009 09:10AM cka0706 wrote: I've been reading all your posts and though I'm scared as hell I feel encouraged. I put the cart before the horse. Yesterday I went to the onc for the first time (already had the bilat mx last month) and my oncotype was high so I'll be joining the chemo clup. After the surgery the SNB came back clear so I thought I was off the hook. Not so lucky. I decided that knowing the oncotype score and being able to hopefully bypass a recurrence is a good thing. But I'm seriously dreading the whole chemo thing. I hate the idea of losing my hair and I only realized yesterday this doesn't mean just the hair on my head (duh!). Eyebrows and eyelashes, too. My first session is December 1 so I think I will start a new "starting chemo in December" thread. Good luck to my fellow warriors out there. I'm thinking of you and relying on your strength and humor.
Posts.Title: November 2009-Starting Chemo BrendaSharon livelife

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2010 01:54PM cka0706 wrote: My hair is being totally weird. After my second tx (TC) my hair started growing! I have 1/8-1/4" of fuzz on my head with an occasional 1" hair strand. I told the onc I think they gave me fake drugs last time! Go figure. But I have two more tx so who knows what will happen. Also, had absolutely no nausea afterwards but today (18 days later) I feel awful -- exhausted and nauseous. I'm confused. Hope everyone is having a good day. Carolyn
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2009 12:26PM cka0706 wrote: I had fibroadenoma many years ago. It was so painful I had to hold my breast when I walked down stairs. I had it removed (under the guise of "biopsy") because the pain really became life limiting. When I was diagnosed with BD (IDC) there was no pain at all.  Good luck.

I know I'll get hungry during that time but not sure what to bring (other than saltines, which I really don't like). Any ideas? Second -- is anyone else allowed in the treatment room with you? My dear friend offered to stay with me and I loved the idea. (Some people I wouldn't allow in the treatment room ever - too negative!).  Would love your thoughts on this. Carolyn

Posts.Title: More Tips (and a Shopping List) for Getting Through Chemo rock MinusTwo

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2009 06:00PM cka0706 wrote: Hi everyone. I made it throught my first chemo yesterday. My dear friend drove 2 hours to sit with me. I fell asleep after the first hour but she was smart enough to bring her laptop and work while I snoozed. We went out to lunch afterwards. It's good to have such caring friends. Chemo brain hit hard and fast. I couldn't remember some pretty routine stuff and I can't type at all anymore. Plus I'm so hyper from the steroids. Weird. I got a Neulasta shot today (hurt like crazy) and I'm not looking forward to bone pain, but I've had 2 nasty infections this year that landed me in the hospital so the onc isn't taking any chances.  My biggest accomplishment today is buying a wig. I put that off because I didn't want to think about losing my hair. I think next week I'll get a short cut (my hair is shoulder length). I asked my 25-year-old son if he wants to give me the buzz cut when I'm ready for it. I told him the decision was his but he thought that was pretty cool. I love the tips and I re-read them now that they're more specific to my needs. So thanks for sharing them! I definitely want to find the Gin-gin drops at Whole Foods. Dry mouth is a problem. Good wishes to my chemo sisters! Carolyn
Posts.Title: More Tips (and a Shopping List) for Getting Through Chemo rock MinusTwo

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2009 04:24AM cka0706 wrote: Hi Ginnie, Grandbabies! How wonderful. I'm not quite there yet, though my children are 25 and 18. Some of my friends are entering the grandparent stage. I'm looking forward to it but it will wait a few years :)  Good luck with treatment. I 'll look for you on the "Holiday Chemo" pages. Carolyn
Posts.Title: More Tips (and a Shopping List) for Getting Through Chemo rock MinusTwo

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2009 04:44PM cka0706 wrote: Hi Cammy, I've often said that I can handle any crisis ... I just fall apart afterwards. The best advice I got is that it's a combination of "auto-pilot" and "adrenaline". I agree with that. And everyone has their own time and own way of grieving, you just have to be patient with yourself.  You're right that it's very hard to worry family and friends. Their sadness is hard to handle but I realized it's because they really care about me, which is truly wonderful! Don't be afraid to tell you family and friends what you can and cannot hear. In other words, if someone starts telling you something you don't want to hear -- even if it's just a difficult day and you don't want to talk -- tell them. I was terrible about saying this sort of thing but quickly learned I needed to do that. There were days when talking just exhausted me. If someone called, I thanked them for calling and said it was too tiring to talk that day and I hope they understood. They did and they are true friends. So this is the time to let family and friends be there for you. Amazingly, letting them do things really helps them ... things like bringing dinner, sending cards or magazines, dropping off flowers make them feel good and really perked me up.  Good luck with you surgery. I will be thinking of you. Let us know how everything turns out. Carolyn

Posts.Content: cka0706 wrote: I was diagnosed in June (IDC + DCIS in right; DCIS in left). I had a bilateral mastectomy w/ implants in October followed 2 weeks later by a 6-day hospitals stay for a staph infection. I had another 10 days of at-home IV antibiotics. Finally done with all of that. Oh -- the reason for the delay between diagnosis and surgery was so I could get my daughter off to college (I wasn't in denial, really!). I handled everything fine but for some reason today it feels like it all caught up with me. Oddly, I never cried when I suspected or heard the "breast cancer" diagnosis, not when I had surgery, not when the infection showed up, not dragging around the IV pump. Why today? Has anyone had a delayed reaction? TC x 4 starting 12/1/09. When the going gets tough, the tough eat chocolate. Dx 6/17/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Been handling this ... until today cka0706 kel1
